citeinfo.origin: Center for Geospatial Data Analysis (CGDA) (data compiler)
citeinfo.title: AQUIFERS_UNCONSOLIDATED_USGS_IN: Unconsolidated Aquifer Systems in Indiana (United States Geological Survey, 1:500,000, Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: Data is compiled from: Fenelon, J.M., Bobay, K.E., Greeman, T.K., Hoover, M.E., Cohen, D.A., Fowler, K.K., Woodfield, M.C., Doss, P.K., and Durbin, J.M., 1994, Hydrogeologic atlas of aquifers in Indiana, U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142, 197 p. <http://in.water.usgs.gov/atlasweb/>

descript.abstract: Five types of unconsolidated aquifers in 12 water-management basins identified by the Indiana Natural Resources Commission (INRC) in Indiana were identified by the USGS in U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142 (Fenelon and others, 1994). The source scale of the maps depicting aquifers was 1:500,000. Aquifer maps are based on information from hydrogeologic sections and from previous studies. Attributes were compiled from tabular information contained in Fenelon and others (1994). Information contained in the report was used to identify mapped rock units within aquifer systems and distribute the aquifer characteristics to those polygons.
descript.purpose: These data are intended for use at a scale of 1:500,000 or smaller. Owing to the small scale and sparseness of data used for the aquifer-systems mapping, the primary intended use is for regional data display and analysis, rather than specific local or site-specific data analysis.
descript.supplinf:
The following is excerpted from Fenelon and others (1994, page 1):
"Unconsolidated aquifers are the most widely used aquifers in Indiana. Types of unconsolidated aquifers include surficial, buried, and discontinuous layers of sand and gravel. Most of the surficial sand and gravel is located in large outwash plains in northern Indiana and along the major rivers in the southern two-thirds of the State. Buried sand and gravel aquifers underlie much of the northern two-thirds of Indiana, where they are typically interbedded with till deposits and can be 10 to 400 ft deep. Discontinuous sand and gravel deposits are present as isolated lenses, primarily in glaciated areas."
A LYR (Aquifers_unconsolidated_USGS_IN.lyr) file accompanies this data layer to assist the user with symbolization so that the vertical sequence of aquifer systems can be visualized in geographic information system (GIS) software, particularly ESRI software products.

theme.themekey: discontinuous buried sand and gravel aquifer
discontinuous surficial sand and gravel aquifer

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcGIS shapefile format, Microsoft Windows XP, approximately 4.93 MB

attracc.attraccr: The content of the attributes contained in this layer are as reported in Fenelon and others, 1994. The accuracy of these attributes is not known. The accuracy of the reported aquifer characteristics is not intended to represent site-specific conditions, but to identify types of aquifers and typical extents of rock units likely to contain and produce ground water. The thickness ranges and potential aquifer yield ranges are estimates of regional aquifer characteristics.

dataqual.logic: Checks for sliver polygons were conducted and resolved by attributing the slivers with the "Aquifer_Type" value of the adjacent polygon in the same "Basin" and dissolving the boundaries. No topological checks were conducted on this data set. The shapefile represents a vertical distribution of aquifers, and the polygon boundaries overlap. In places with overlapping aquifer system polygons, more than one potential aquifer exists.
dataqual.complete: Layer includes statewide data of unconsolidated aquifers including aquifer type, local names, thickness, and potential aquifer yield as presented in the USGS publication Hydrogeologic atlas of aquifers in Indiana (Fenelon and others, 1994). Where a type of aquifer was less than 15 square miles in areal extent, it was not mapped because of scale limitations. Buried unconsolidated valleys were mapped where productive aquifers are within them. "Buried aquifer" indicates that the sand and gravel is covered by 10 ft or more of nonaquifer material and that the deposits are continuous in at least one direction for several miles or more. "Discontinuous aquifer" refers to lenses of sand and gravel that are not laterally extensive. "Surficial aquifer" indicates that the aquifer is covered by less than 10 ft of nonaquifer material.

horizpa.horizpar: The source publication (Fenelon, 1994) reports no information on horizontal accuracy of the original 1:500,000 mapping. Horizontal accuracy is largely contingent upon accuracy of the source publication. ESRI ArcGIS was used to georeference vector data using county boundaries.

vertacc.vertaccr: Vertical accuracy was not a factor in the digital production of the data set.

citeinfo.title: Fenelon, J.M., Bobay, K.E., Greeman, T.K., Hoover, M.E., Cohen, D.A., Fowler, K.K., Woodfield, M.C., Doss, P.K., and Durbin, J.M., 1994, Hydrogeologic atlas of aquifers in Indiana, U.S. Geological Survey Water-Resources Investigations Report 92-4142, 197 p.
citeinfo.othercit:
Tabular data in Fenelon and others (1994) provided the content of the attribute table built for this data layer. The tables used for the aquifers in each water management basin are as follows:
Lake Michigan River Basin aquifers: Table 3, page 23
St Joseph River Basin aquifers: Table 4, page 33
Kankakee River Basin aquifers: Table 5, page 47
Maumee River Basin aquifers: Table 6, page 61
Upper Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 7, page 81
Middle Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 8, page 99
Lower Wabash River Basin aquifers: Table 9, page 110
White River Basin aquifers: Table 10, page 132
East Fork White River Basin aquifers: Table 11, page 153
Whitewater River Basin aquifers: Table 12, page 164
Patoka River Basin aquifers: Table 13, page 174
Ohio River Basin aquifers: Table 14, page 196

srcinfo.srccitea: USGS Hydrogeologic Atlas for Indiana; Fenelon and others, 1994
srcinfo.srccontr: Mapped aquifer polygons and tabular data for building the attribute table

citeinfo.title: WATERSHEDS_HUC14_SUBWATERSHEDS_USGS_IN: Subwatersheds, 14-digit, Hydrologic Units, in Indiana, (United States Geological Survey, 1:24,000 Polygon Shapefile)
LANDSURVEY_COUNTY_POLY_IN: County Boundaries of Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, 1:24,000, Polygon Shapefile)

srcinfo.srccontr: Base data for georeferencing original aquifer systems boundaries from Fenelon and others (1994)

procstep.procdesc: USGS personnel provided IGS personnel with EPS (image) files of the extents of bedrock aquifer systems for each water management basin in Indiana, as presented in the Hydrogeologic Atlas of Aquifers in Indiana publication (Fenelon and others, 1994). IGS personnel exported the data from Adobe Illustrator as PNG files at 900 dpi with a transparent background. The PNG files were geoferenced in ESRI ArcMap to LANDSURVEY_COUNTY_POLY_IN.shp and the mapped aquifer boundaries were digitized using the "Trace" function of the ArcMap Editor Toolbar. Any water management basin boundaries retained during the georeferencing and digitization of the aquifer system boundaries were dissolved using the "Aquifer_Type" attribute to create continuous aquifer system layers.
procstep.srcused: Figures from USGS Hydrogeologic Atlas for Indiana
procstep.srcprod: bbva_state.shp (buried bedrock valley aquifer), bsga_state.shp (buried sand and gravel aquifer), dsga_state.shp (discontinuous buried sand and gravel aquifer), dssga_state.shp (discontinuous surficial sand and gravel aquifer), ssga_state.shp (surficial sand and gravel aquifer).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: The Indiana Natural Resources Commission (INRC) water management basin boundaries were replicated using 1:24,000-scale HUC14 subwatershed boundaries. This step was conducted for two reasons: (1) the 1:500,000-scale source maps with the original river basin boundaries were not coincident with other mapped HUC6 (major river basin hydrologic units) boundaries for Indiana, and (2) the quality of the basin boundaries after tracing from the EPS/PNG image files was poor.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: Each aquifer system was combined using the "Union" tool in ESRI ArcMap with the reconstructed INRC basin boundaries to discretize the aquifer systems in preparation for joining with an attribute table of aquifer characteristics compiled from Fenelon and others (1994).
procstep.srcused: bbva_state.shp, bsga_state.shp, dsga_state.shp, dssga_state.shp, ssga_state.shp, basins_state.shp.
procstep.srcprod: bbva_basins.shp (buried bedrock valley aquifer), bsga_basins.shp (buried sand and gravel aquifer), dsga_basins.shp (discontinuous buried sand and gravel aquifer), dssga_basins.shp (discontinuous surficial sand and gravel aquifer), ssga_basins.shp (surficial sand and gravel aquifer).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: An attribute table of aquifer types and characteristics was compiled from tabular information in Fenelon and others, 1994. A unique ID was assigned to each combination of basin, aquifer system, and local name (if the aquifer system and local name were associated by unique aquifer characteristics such as thickness and/or aquifer yield).

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: The unique ID assigned to each basin and aquifer system was added to the attribute tables of each shapefile to serve as a join field to append the compiled aquifer data to the spatial data. The individual aquifer system polygons per basin were dissolved in ArcMap using the ID field to remove sliver polygons. The individual basin aquifer system layers were merged together to create continuous statewide aquifer system layers.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: The attribute tables of the output files were checked for uniformity, and all aquifer systems were merged into a single shapefile in ESRI ArcMap to create an unconsolidated aquifer system data layer for Indiana.

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

procstep.procdesc: This metadata file was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v. 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v. 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (U.S. Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."

cntperp.cntorg: Indiana Geological Survey, Indiana University Center for Geospatial Data Analysis

edom.edomv: Discontinuous buried sand and gravel aquifer
edom.edomvd: discontinuous buried sand and gravel aquifer

edom.edomv: Discontinuous surficial sand and gravel aquifer
edom.edomvd: discontinuous surficial sand and gravel aquifer

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number assigned to river basin and aquifer systems in Indiana

edom.edomvd: East Fork White River water management basin
Lake Michigan (in Indiana) water management basin
Lower Wabash River water management basin
Middle Wabash River water management basin
Ohio River (in Indiana) water management basin
St. Joseph River water management basin
Upper Wabash River water management basin

attr.attrdef: Local aquifer names and types. Many aquifers have multiple local names cited by various authors. The literature sources for each local name are listed in the field named "Name_cite"
Literature sources for local aquifer names cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various names given in the field named "Local_name"

Estimated aquifer thickness range (in feet) for aquifer system. Various thickness ranges correspond to various aquifer units given in the field "Local_name" and various literature sources given in the field named "Thk_cite"
Literature sources for aquifer thickness ranges cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various thickness ranges given in the field named "Thk_ft"

Potential aquifer yield range (gallons per minute) estimated for aquifer system. Various yield ranges correspond to various aquifer units given in the field "Local_name" and various literature sources given in the field named "Yield_cite"
Maximum potential aquifer yield estimated for aquifer system

rdom.rdommin: 0 (value of zero means no yield range was reported)
rdom.attrmres: 1 gallon per minute, but usually rounded to 10 gpm

attr.attrdef: Literature sources for aquifer yield cited in Fenelon and others, 1994. Various sources correspond to various yield ranges given in the field named "Yield_gpm"

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It is not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
